utterances: Welcome, Joe.
Thanks for having me, Linda.
The subprime woes.
Now that was the big business joy of 2007.
And is it going to continue to be a big story in 2008 and beyond?
Most certainly, on two levels.
It's had an incredible effect both on Wall Street and on Main Street.
On the Wall Street level, how much worse is it going to get?
I mean, Wall Street banks have already written off billions of dollars in mortgage paper that they held.
And they're going to write off billions more in the coming year.
Nobody knows how bad it's going to be.
And the same is true on Main Street.
The truth of the matter is there is going to be an enormous number of foreclosures in 2008 and probably into 2009.
Probably well over a million people will lose their homes because they signed onto mortgages that they couldn't really afford.
And your house is probably worth less today than it was at the beginning of the year.
And there's a very good chance it will be worth less at the end of 2008 than it is today.
Is this the end of the Greenspan era?
Mr. Greenspan has been defending himself lately against what he admits were some missteps, I suppose, failure to regulate?
In Alan Greenspan's world, all the missteps appear to have been made by other people.
His record is not very good on this issue.
He could have done things earlier.
He could have tried to tighten standards.
He could have, at least used his bully pulpit to raise alarms about subprime and he did none of that.

The most telling fact is that the current Fed chairman, Ben Bernanke, is behind the Federal Reserve effort, which will do exactly what Greenspan didn't do, which is tighten lending standards and make it harder to give loans to people who can't afford to pay them back.
Let's move on to China, which was another big business story in 2007.
I think most of us focused on the recalls of defective and dangerous toys.
Do you think that everybody looking at China as we think about the Beijing Olympics?
Will we see China change?
I do think China will change on this issue, but not necessarily because of the Olympics.
If you're going to have globalization, everybody has to be able to play by the same rules, and everybody has to be able to count on the other party to do what they're supposed to do.
So what's really going to happen is economics is going to solve this problem.
It's a good lesson for the Chinese that contracts, global rules are there for a reason, and you renege on them or ignore them at your economic peril.
Let's move on to the tech sector.
The iPhone was introduced.
How was it doing?
It's a hit.
And are people going to develop new products and compete, and make it even more interesting in 2008?
Oh, absolutely.
People are going to devise products that look more and more like the iPhone.
But you're going to see all of these devices kind of merge and compete.
And, you know, Google is another company that's done extraordinary well this year.
And one of the big rumors for 2008 is that Google will get into the cell phone business and begin to not just make mobile software but basically cell phones.
So can Google keep doing this, just pushing and pushing - the sky is the limit?
OK, Estonia.
Estonia, nice.
Stephanie Meyer - M-E-Y-E-R.
First and foremost, the idea of having an African-American family on television - you know, in a drama - really attracted me to the project.
And moreover, the fact that it focuses on an African-American male lead.
And, you know, so often we talk about black men selling crack-rock and having wicked jump shots and whatnot, but not really being leaders in their community.
And I think that Eddie Sutton is really, he is a leader of his community and he loves his community and he loves his people.
Let's get a little more specific in terms of your character Eddie Sutton and how much, if any, of Eddie Sutton is Russell?
I've created the character based on two family members of mine who work in law enforcement and government in the Roxbury section of Boston, Massachusetts.
Two uncles of mine, Franklin and Edward Red(ph) - one is a judge and the other is a constable.
They live in Roxbury, you know, and they live among their people.
And my uncle's a judge and he sends, you know, young people to jail or he gives them, you know, a second chance, you know, to get their life back in order.
And that is what I wanted to focus on, that Eddie, he physically left, but his spirit was always there.
That really came through for me in the scene where, in this robbery, where you - your character, Eddie Sutton, had to shoot and kill - well, you shoot and kill the kid who he was trying...
That's right.
...to help.
And in his face, you could see that he was really, really pained by that.
Well, yeah, I mean, he was.
And that, I think, that's something that's going to, you know, live on with him for the rest of his days because of that very notion that, you know, when one goes down, we all go down.
(Soundbite from TV show, ""Lincoln Height"")
(Soundbite of heavy breathing)
Unidentified Man: You know what?
I was actually thinking about taking that nasty class of yours.
(As Eddie Sutton) You can still do it.
Unidentified Man: I can't (unintelligible) to do gymnastics.

Let me ask you, Kathleen, were you concerned at all about how believable it would be for a middle-class black family to decide to put their children in an environment that is dangerous - physically dangerous - as a story that would have credibility (unintelligible)?
Well, in this particular instance, our hero, Eddie Sutton, grew up in this neighborhood.
So he knows the soul of these people.
He knows the heart of these people.
And, indeed, he realizes that there are some elements that are dangerous.
But at the same time he knows that as many dangerous people as there are, there are more people there who really want to make this neighborhood a good place to live.
And this character would not put his family who he treasures above all else in a situation he knows he cannot protect them in.
How does diversity play into how you are building Lincoln Heights?
The neighborhood of Lincoln Heights is a diverse community, and we have characters who really reflect that.
The school that Cassie goes to - our teenage daughter - is an interracial situation.
She has a boyfriend who's white.
Eddie's partner is a white cop.
There are white cops predominantly in the police precinct where Eddie works.
Criminals in our neighborhood are not just black criminals.
That's true.
It's an equal opportunity situation in terms of what's going down on the street.
And so, it's not monolithic in terms of a black point of view.
Black-themed dramas have had various success on television, both broadcast and cable.
Do you think that ""Lincoln Heights"" has something special - either in terms of the people involved or the time that it is been brought to us -that will help make it successful?
The time is right.
You know, our community is ready for something different.
I think they're ready for a show that reflects who we are as individuals and the amount of humanity that we have.

So, you know, I really believe that the community - not just the black community - but, you know, America is ready to support this kind of show because I think it's not only an African-American, you know, story or perspective.
It's an American story and perspective.
My first experience on TV as a baby writer was working on ""Little House on the Prairie."" I was hired by Michael Landon to do a well-told story about a family.
And I've been pursuing that endeavor ever since.
I've been trying to tell stories about families, and in particularly from the African-American point of view.
So this is a time - how many years later are we talking here, 30?
Where we have Barack Obama and we have Condoleezza Rice and we have hip-hop and all these images that have really become a part of the consciousness of our times.
So I think sensibility and time has also really tempered audiences.
And I think it's time for them to really embrace - in a colorblind sense - a family that has values and emotions that are transcendent of race.
So, Monday nights, 7 o'clock, ABC Family, ""Lincoln Heights."" It's good.
Thank you very much.
Thank you so much.
It's good.
That was NPR's Tony Cox with ""Lincoln Heights'"" star Russell Hornsby and executive producer Kathleen McGhee-Anderson.
Time now for StoryCorps.
The OutLoud initiative collects stories from the LGBTQ community.
And today, we're sharing one of them with you - a story about the fierce bond between two men Doug Neville and Ryan Johnson.
They met in 1986 shortly before Doug learned he was HIV-positive.
They sat down in a StoryCorps recording booth to talk about their three decades of friendship.
I never really had a lot of friends through grade school or high school, college even.
I was frequently bullied.
And so I was thought, what's wrong with me?
And when we first started hanging out, I remember thinking I, you know, wanted to be your friend.
And I knew how to get a man into bed.
(Laughter).
But I didn't know how to ask for a friendship.
Why would he want to be a friend to me?
Alex, there's a divide here in terms of interest and it doesn't break down along party lines.

What you have is people like Senator Specter, you know, well respected, someone with great experience on the Judiciary Committee saying that basically the Justice Department is a broken institution with Alberto Gonzales as its leader and it's unable to really not only continue efforts to make sure that there is expansion of intelligence gathering in the face of efforts to thwart terrorists, but the very credibility of the justice system itself is at stake given the problems and issues that have arisen in light of the firing of the prosecutors, the U.S.
prosecutors.
The White House interests are altogether on a different side of the world, Alex.
They feel that if you have a hearing for a new attorney general, it will raise all sorts of issues and force them to confront questions they don't want to face.

Secondly, Fred Fielding, who has been out of the White House counsel, is trying to hold at bay investigators and subpoenas of all manner, and he doesn't want an aggressive Justice Department feeling that they have to prove their credibility to the Congress, you know, sacrificing the White House in the process.
